column2: Upon the night when Nancy, having lulled Mr. Sikes to sleep, hurried on her self-imposed mission to Rose Maylie, there advanced towards London, by the Great North Road, two persons, upon whom it is expedient that this history should bestow some attention.
column3: Upon the night when Nancy, having lulled mr Sikes to sleep, hurried on her self imposed mission to Rose Maylie, there advanced towards London, by the Great North Road, two persons, upon whom it is expedient that this history should bestow some attention.

column2: They were a man and woman; or perhaps they would be better described as a male and female: for the former was one of those long-limbed, knock-kneed, shambling, bony people, to whom it is difficult to assign any precise age,--looking as they do, when they are yet boys, like undergrown men, and when they are almost men, like overgrown boys.

column2: The woman was young, but of a robust and hardy make, as she need have been to bear the weight of the heavy bundle which was strapped to her back. column2: I shall go and lose myself among the narrowest streets I can find, and not stop till we come to the very out-of-the-wayest house I can set eyes on. column2: Now, this back-room was immediately behind the bar, and some steps lower, so that any person connected with the house, undrawing a small curtain which concealed a single pane of glass fixed in the wall of the last-named apartment, about five feet from its flooring, could not only look down upon any guests in the back-room without any great hazard of being observed (the glass being in a dark angle of the wall, between which and a large upright beam the observer had to thrust himself), but could, by applying his ear to the partition, ascertain with tolerable distinctness, their subject of conversation.

column3: Noah Claypole's mind might have been at ease after this assurance, but his body certainly was not; for he shuffled and writhed about, into various uncouth positions: eyeing his new friend meanwhile with mingled fear and suspicion.

column2: 'I'll tell you more,' said Fagin, after he had reassured the girl, by dint of friendly nods and muttered encouragements.
column3: 'I'll tell you more,' said Fagin, after he had reassured the girl, by dint of friendly nods and muttered encouragements.

column2: 'I have got a friend that I think can gratify your darling wish, and put you in the right way, where you can take whatever department of the business you think will suit you best at first, and be taught all the others.'
column3: 'I have got a friend that I think can gratify your darling wish, and put you in the right way, where you can take whatever department of the business you think will suit you best at first, and be taught all the others.'

column2: 'Yer speak as if yer were in earnest,' replied Noah.
column3: 'Yer speak as if yer were in earnest,' replied Noah.

column2: 'What advantage would it be to me to be anything else?' inquired Fagin, shrugging his shoulders.
column3: 'What advantage would it be to me to be anything else?' inquired Fagin, shrugging his shoulders.

column2: 'Here!

column2: Let me have a word with you outside.'

column2: 'There's no occasion to trouble ourselves to move,' said Noah, getting his legs by gradual degrees abroad again.
column3: 'There's no occasion to trouble ourselves to move,' said Noah, getting his legs by gradual degrees abroad again.

column2: 'She'll take the luggage upstairs the while.

column2: Charlotte, see to them bundles.'

column2: This mandate, which had been delivered with great majesty, was obeyed without the slightest demur; and Charlotte made the best of her way off with the packages while Noah held the door open and watched her out.
column3: This mandate, which had been delivered with great majesty, was obeyed without the slightest demur; and Charlotte made the best of her way off with the packages while Noah held the door open and watched her out.

column2: 'She's kept tolerably well under, ain't she?' he asked as he resumed his seat: in the tone of a keeper who had tamed some wild animal.
column3: 'She's kept tolerably well under, ain't she?' he asked as he resumed his seat: in the tone of a keeper who had tamed some wild animal.

column2: 'Quite perfect,' rejoined Fagin, clapping him on the shoulder.
column3: 'Quite perfect,' rejoined Fagin, clapping him on the shoulder.

column2: 'You're a genius, my dear.'
column3: 'You're a genius, my dear.'

column2: 'Why, I suppose if I wasn't, I shouldn't be here,' replied Noah. 'But, I say, she'll be back if yer lose time.'
column3: 'Why, I suppose if I wasn't, I shouldn't be here,' replied Noah. 'But, I say, she'll be back if yer lose time.'

column2: 'Now, what do you think?' said Fagin. 'If you was to like my friend, could you do better than join him?'
column3: 'Now, what do you think?' said Fagin. 'If you was to like my friend, could you do better than join him?'

column2: 'Is he in a good way of business; that's where it is!' responded Noah, winking one of his little eyes.
column3: 'Is he in a good way of business; that's where it is!' responded Noah, winking one of his little eyes.

column2: 'The top of the tree; employs a power of hands; has the very best society in the profession.'
column3: 'The top of the tree; employs a power of hands; has the very best society in the profession.'

column2: 'Regular town-maders?' asked Mr. Claypole.
column3: 'Regular town maders?' asked mr Claypole.

column2: 'Not a countryman among 'em; and I don't think he'd take you, even on my recommendation, if he didn't run rather short of assistants just now,' replied Fagin.
column3: 'Not a countryman among 'em; and I don't think he'd take you, even on my recommendation, if he didn't run rather short of assistants just now,' replied Fagin.

column2: 'Should I have to hand over?' said Noah, slapping his breeches-pocket.
column3: 'Should I have to hand over?' said Noah, slapping his breeches pocket.

column2: 'It couldn't possibly be done without,' replied Fagin, in a most decided manner.
column3: 'It couldn't possibly be done without,' replied Fagin, in a most decided manner.

column2: 'Twenty pound, though--it's a lot of money!'
column3: 'Twenty pound, though-it's a lot of money!'

column2: 'Not when it's in a note you can't get rid of,' retorted Fagin. 'Number and date taken, I suppose?
column3: 'Not when it's in a note you can't get rid of,' retorted Fagin. 'Number and date taken, I suppose?

column2: It's not worth much to him.

column2: It'll have to go abroad, and he couldn't sell it for a great deal in the market.'
column3: It'll have to go abroad, and he couldn't sell it for a great deal in the market.'

column2: 'When could I see him?' asked Noah doubtfully.
column3: 'When could I see him?' asked Noah doubtfully.

column2: 'To-morrow morning.'
column3: 'To morrow morning.'

column2: 'Where?'

column2: 'Here.'

column2: 'Um!' said Noah. 'What's the wages?'
column3: 'Um!' said Noah. 'What's the wages?'

column2: 'Live like a gentleman--board and lodging, pipes and spirits free--half of all you earn, and half of all the young woman earns,' replied Mr. Fagin.
column3: 'Live like a gentleman-board and lodging, pipes and spirits free-half of all you earn, and half of all the young woman earns,' replied mr Fagin.

column2: Whether Noah Claypole, whose rapacity was none of the least comprehensive, would have acceded even to these glowing terms, had he been a perfectly free agent, is very doubtful; but as he recollected that, in the event of his refusal, it was in the power of his new acquaintance to give him up to justice immediately (and more unlikely things had come to pass), he gradually relented, and said he thought that would suit him.
column3: Whether Noah Claypole, whose rapacity was none of the least comprehensive, would have acceded even to these glowing terms, had he been a perfectly free agent, is very doubtful; but as he recollected that, in the event of his refusal, it was in the power of his new acquaintance to give him up to justice immediately (and more unlikely things had come to pass), he gradually relented, and said he thought that would suit him.

column2: 'But, yer see,' observed Noah, 'as she will be able to do a good deal, I should like to take something very light.'
column3: 'But, yer see,' observed Noah, 'as she will be able to do a good deal, I should like to take something very light.'

column2: 'A little fancy work?' suggested Fagin.
column3: 'A little fancy work?' suggested Fagin.

column2: 'Ah! something of that sort,' replied Noah. 'What do you think would suit me now?
column3: 'Ah! something of that sort,' replied Noah. 'What do you think would suit me now?

column2: Something not too trying for the strength, and not very dangerous, you know.

column2: That's the sort of thing!'

column2: 'I heard you talk of something in the spy way upon the others, my dear,' said Fagin. 'My friend wants somebody who would do that well, very much.'
column3: 'I heard you talk of something in the spy way upon the others, my dear,' said Fagin. 'My friend wants somebody who would do that well, very much.'

column2: 'Why, I did mention that, and I shouldn't mind turning my hand to it sometimes,' rejoined Mr. Claypole slowly; 'but it wouldn't pay by itself, you know.'
column3: 'Why, I did mention that, and I shouldn't mind turning my hand to it sometimes,' rejoined mr Claypole slowly; 'but it wouldn't pay by itself, you know.'

column2: 'That's true!' observed the Jew, ruminating or pretending to ruminate. 'No, it might not.'
column3: 'That's true!' observed the Jew, ruminating or pretending to ruminate. 'No, it might not.'

column2: 'What do you think, then?' asked Noah, anxiously regarding him. 'Something in the sneaking way, where it was pretty sure work, and not much more risk than being at home.'
column3: 'What do you think, then?' asked Noah, anxiously regarding him. 'Something in the sneaking way, where it was pretty sure work, and not much more risk than being at home.'

column2: 'What do you think of the old ladies?' asked Fagin. 'There's a good deal of money made in snatching their bags and parcels, and running round the corner.'
column3: 'What do you think of the old ladies?' asked Fagin. 'There's a good deal of money made in snatching their bags and parcels, and running round the corner.'

column2: 'Don't they holler out a good deal, and scratch sometimes?' asked Noah, shaking his head.
column3: 'Don't they holler out a good deal, and scratch sometimes?' asked Noah, shaking his head.

column2: 'I don't think that would answer my purpose.

column2: Ain't there any other line open?'

column2: 'Stop!' said Fagin, laying his hand on Noah's knee.
column3: 'Stop!' said Fagin, laying his hand on Noah's knee.

column2: 'The kinchin lay.'
column3: 'The kinchin lay.'

column2: 'What's that?' demanded Mr. Claypole.
column3: 'What's that?' demanded mr Claypole.

column2: 'The kinchins, my dear,' said Fagin, 'is the young children that's sent on errands by their mothers, with sixpences and shillings; and the lay is just to take their money away--they've always got it ready in their hands,--then knock 'em into the kennel, and walk off very slow, as if there were nothing else the matter but a child fallen down and hurt itself.
column3: 'The kinchins, my dear,' said Fagin, 'is the young children that's sent on errands by their mothers, with sixpences and shillings; and the lay is just to take their money away-they've always got it ready in their hands,--then knock 'em into the kennel, and walk off very slow, as if there were nothing else the matter but a child fallen down and hurt itself.
